sections.text: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws.
sections.simple: Equality before Law: No one is above the law, not even politicians or celebrities.

sections.text: Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex or place of birth.
sections.simple: No Discrimination: The state cannot treat you unfairly based on your background.

sections.text: All citizens shall have the right to freedom of speech and expression.
sections.simple: Freedom of Speech: You can express your opinion freely (but cannot incite violence or defame others).

sections.text: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
sections.simple: Right to Life: The most powerful right. It includes the right to privacy, health, and dignity.

sections.text: The State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to fourteen years.
sections.simple: Right to Education: Every child has a fundamental right to go to school.

sections.text: Traffic in human beings and begar and other similar forms of forced labour are prohibited.
sections.simple: No Forced Labor: Human trafficking and slavery are strictly banned.

sections.text: No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine.
sections.simple: No Child Labor: Children cannot be hired for dangerous jobs.

sections.text: Remedies for enforcement of rights conferred by this Part.
sections.simple: Constitutional Remedies: You can approach the Supreme Court directly if your fundamental rights are violated.

sections.text: Fundamental Duties: To abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions...
sections.simple: Your Duties: Respect the flag, protect public property, and preserve the environment.

sections.text: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention.
sections.simple: Common Intention: If a group commits a crime together, each member is equally responsible.
Conspiracy: Planning a crime with someone else is a punishable offense, even if the crime hasn't happened yet.
Sedition: Words or actions that incite hatred or violence against the Government of India.
A gathering of 5 or more people with the intent to commit a crime or disturb peace.

sections.text: Disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant.
sections.simple: Disobeying Official Orders: Like violating a curfew or COVID lockdown rules.
Public Obscenity: Doing obscene acts or singing obscene songs in public is a crime.
Murder: Intentional killing of another human being.
Negligent Death: Causing death carelessly (e.g., reckless driving), but without intent to kill.
Attempted Murder: Trying to kill someone but failing. Punishable with up to 10 years in jail.
Suicide Attempt: (Note: Largely decriminalized by Mental Healthcare Act, but still exists in IPC).
Simple Hurt: Slapping, punching, or hitting someone causing pain but no major injury.

sections.text: Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty.
sections.simple: Outraging Modesty: Inappropriate physical contact or behavior towards a woman.
Rape: Sexual intercourse without consent. Consent obtained by fear or fraud is invalid.
Theft: Taking someone's movable property without their consent.
Extortion: Forcing someone to give property or money by threatening them with injury.
Robbery: Theft or extortion accomplished by causing fear of instant death or hurt.
Cheating: Deceiving someone to make them deliver property or consent to something harmful.

sections.text: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property.
sections.simple: Fraud/420: A serious form of cheating involving property or money.

sections.text: Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty.
sections.simple: Dowry Harassment: Cruelty towards a wife by her husband or in-laws.
Defamation: Damaging someone's reputation by publishing false statements.
Intimidation: Threatening to harm someone's person, reputation, or property.

sections.text: Word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman.
sections.simple: Eve Teasing: Making sounds, gestures, or comments that insult a woman's dignity.

sections.text: Notice of appearance before police officer.
sections.simple: Notice Instead of Arrest: For crimes punishable by less than 7 years, police should issue a notice first, not arrest immediately.
No Night Arrest for Women: A woman cannot be arrested after sunset and before sunrise, except in exceptional circumstances.

sections.text: Person arrested to be informed of grounds of arrest and of right to bail.
sections.simple: Right to Know: Police must tell you WHY you are being arrested and if the offense is bailable.

sections.text: Person arrested not to be detained more than twenty-four hours.
sections.simple: The 24-Hour Rule: Police cannot hold you for more than 24 hours without producing you before a Magistrate.

sections.text: Order for maintenance of wives, children and parents.
sections.simple: Maintenance: A person must provide financial support to their wife, children, or aging parents if they cannot support themselves.

sections.text: Power to issue order in urgent cases of nuisance or apprehended danger.
sections.simple: Section 144: An order banning the assembly of 4 or more people in an area to prevent trouble.
First Information Report (FIR): The police MUST register an FIR if a serious (cognizable) crime is reported.

sections.text: Direction for grant of bail to person apprehending arrest.
sections.simple: Anticipatory Bail: Getting bail BEFORE you are arrested if you fear false implication.
Valid Contract: An agreement is only legal if made by free consent, competent parties, and for a lawful object.
Capacity: Minors (under 18) and persons of unsound mind cannot sign legal contracts.
Consent: Two people agree on the same thing in the same sense.

sections.text: Agreement in restraint of trade, void.
sections.simple: Restraint of Trade: You cannot sign a contract that bans someone from practicing a lawful profession.

sections.text: Compensation for loss or damage caused by breach of contract.
sections.simple: Breach Penalty: If someone breaks a contract, they must pay for the loss caused to the other party.
Helmet Rule: Riding a two-wheeler without a helmet is illegal.
Show Papers: You must produce your license and registration when asked by a uniformed officer.

sections.text: Driving vehicles in contravention of section 3 or section 4.
sections.simple: No License: Driving without a valid license can lead to a heavy fine or jail.
Rash Driving: Speeding, jumping red lights, or using a phone while driving.

sections.text: Driving by a drunken person or by a person under the influence of drugs.
sections.simple: Drunk Driving: Driving with alcohol in your blood (above 30mg/100ml) is a criminal offense.

sections.text: Penalty for not wearing a helmet.
sections.simple: Helmet Fine: The fine is â‚¹1000 and disqualification of license for 3 months.

sections.text: Penalty and compensation for damage to computer, computer system, etc.
sections.simple: Hacking/Data Theft: Accessing or copying data from someone's computer without permission is punishable.
Identity Theft: Using someone else's password or digital signature fraudulently.

sections.text: Punishment for cheating by personation by using computer resource.
sections.simple: Phishing: Impersonating someone online to cheat people (e.g., fake bank emails).
Privacy Violation: Capturing or sharing private images of a person without consent.

sections.text: Punishment for publishing or transmitting obscene material in electronic form.
sections.simple: Online Obscenity: Sending or posting vulgar/pornographic content electronically.
The 6 Rights: Right to Safety, Information, Choice, Representation, Redressal, and Education.

sections.text: Manner in which complaint shall be made.
sections.simple: Filing Complaints: You can file a consumer complaint easily, even without a lawyer.
Ignoring Orders: If a company ignores the Consumer Court's order, they can be jailed.

sections.text: Punishment for manufacturing for sale or storing, selling or distributing or importing containing adulterant.
sections.simple: Adulteration: Selling unsafe or adulterated food/products is a criminal offense.
Valid Marriage: Neither party should have a living spouse, and both must be of legal age.
Return Home: If a spouse leaves without reason, the court can order them to return (controversial but valid).
Grounds for Divorce: Adultery, cruelty, desertion, conversion, mental disorder, etc.
Mutual Divorce: The fastest way to separate if both husband and wife agree.

title: Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005

sections.simple: What is Violence: Includes physical, verbal, emotional, sexual, and economic abuse.

sections.text: Right to reside in a shared household.
sections.simple: Right to Residence: A woman cannot be kicked out of her matrimonial home, even if she doesn't own it.
Protection Order: The court can forbid the abuser from contacting or coming near the victim.
Right to Ask: Every citizen has the right to ask questions to public authorities.
How to Ask: Submit a simple application in writing or online. No complex format needed.
30 Day Rule: The officer must reply within 30 days. If it concerns life/liberty, reply within 48 hours.

sections.text: Dishonour of cheque for insufficiency, etc., of funds in the account.
sections.simple: Cheque Bounce: It is a criminal offense if a cheque bounces due to lack of funds. Can lead to 2 years in jail.
Interim Pay: The court can order the accused to pay 20% of the cheque amount to the complainant while the case is ongoing.

title: Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (POSH) Act, 2013

sections.simple: Workplace Safety: No woman shall be subjected to sexual harassment at any workplace.
ICC: Every office with 10+ employees MUST have an Internal Complaints Committee headed by a senior woman.
Filing Complaint: A written complaint must be filed to the ICC within 3 months of the incident.
